ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Rather than a shallow examination of many methods, some of which the students were unlikely to actually implement in their research (judging by the presentations), I would have preferred deeper learning of certain key methods

I think for people who already have a social science research background, the course just covers topics we've already learned in undergraduate classes. For people who have never conducted social science research, they probably got a lot more out of the class. I think Justin's sociological perspective was new to me, so I got to learn some new methods. However, adding these methods made the course less able to go in depth on any one topic, which I felt was a drawback.

Question #4: Amity went too fast in her lectures. Justin's pace was about right. If Amity slows down during each of her lectures, the pace would be perfect. Amity's lectures are packed with excellent information and are extremely interesting but the speed makes it really difficult to process and absorb.

The readings were great in general. We went in a little deeper on a few topics than I thought was helpful for most participants, like in network analysis. While the out of class assignments were useful, I think it would have been better to focus more on aspects of the research proposal. Also, if we had handed in the proposal earlier, we would have then had more of a chance to polish it with the help of the professors, TA's, and other students. It was great to have the two different approached from Amity and Justin on social science research, Amity's being more traditional and Justin's taking advantage of more recent technology.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The chance to discuss our research projects with classmates and the overview of various research methods and techniques.
Working through our research ideas with a group of like-minded peers
The best aspects of the course were getting other students' and the instructors feedback on our own research. It was helpful in designing a proposal. I also liked "practicing the method" homework.
Getting to formulate a research project. Great variety of research methods were discussed.

I really enjoyed Amity's lectures and knowledge. I also really enjoyed sharing my research with a group and receiving feedback. This was the most helpful part of the class.It was enriching to hear all of the other project proposals as well. I wished we got to work in groups more often. I learned a lot here.

I'm a big fan of how Amity and Justin built a comfortable, discussion-based, and close-feeling student experience in the classroom. I also appreciated the amount of time we were encouraged to work in small groups Great breadth of topics (but could be a bad thing (see Q15).
Good for those who need introductory methods
Having a broad overview of many different research methods.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: An increase in the time spent on specifically working through individual research project ideas and design.

The weekly response questions seemed to be kind of cursory, not very challenging or thought provoking. The assignment didn't require significant engagement with the reading and we weren't able to see our classmate's questions, so it seemed like a pretty shallow exercise

I think the course design, as mentioned in question 13. I learned some new methods because we covered wide scope, but at the same time we didn't get to go in depth so that was a drawback. If there was a way to merge the two, that would be the best.
Would have liked to have more focused work on project and have had assignments pertain to project more.
The discussions could be more structured. Also, we could focus more on economics and the more quantitative social sciences. Right now it is focused more on sociology/anthropology type field work.
The class should be taught slower and have students be more prepared for the final presentation and paper. It would be helpful if each part of the final paper were taught in depth.

While we covered a lot of methods this semester (and I appreciate this is probably the point), I don't really feel like I digested them. We only spent one week on interviews AND surveys which make up the bulk of many people's research this coming summer. Other schools similar to FES devote entire classes to this one topic. I felt like we did less practice and more reading/response questions/lecture. I would have really liked the class to be more hands on, especially outside the classroom. Instead of so many readings, maybe a shorter assignment each week where we practiced that week's skill. Readings sometimes seemed repetitive (within each week's set) and often unnecessarily long. Could we be more selective about the readings? Instead of writing reading questions that we often struggled to generate and often weren't discussed in class, could we have more meaningful assignments? I liked having 2 professors to offer different viewpoints but it was often really awkward and embarrassing when Amity would interrupt something Justin said. He has great things to say and it makes students uncomfortable when the profs teaching a "team taught" class aren't really a "team". I found Justin's sections really interesting but often found the lectures to be tedious. Most if not all of the class grew up with computers so we're pretty comfortable with the ideas of "big data" and technological advancement. I would have liked if we could have just skipped to the methods and applications with much less background. We can move faster in this class!

Flexibility for those who are at a more advanced stage in their degree and research, or for those who have already taken at least one (or in my case several) methods and anthropology classes before. (Especially if this class is going to continue to be required for everyone pursuing an MESc.)
It would be great to structure in more of a focus on creating polished research proposals.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Discussion and in-class activities practicing certain methods were good. Since people often tend to sit in the same spots and then group themselves based on seat location, some greater mixing between students for in-class activities might be beneficial
Yes, effective.

The relationship between the course lectures and discussion was effective when the person teaching stopped to engage in conversation.Often times the discussion was curtailed because there was a separate day for discussion. However this "separate" discussion day was usually reserved to discuss readings which were minimally useful. A better way of doing this would be: 1 - slow down on the lectures. The lectures by Amity were very very interesting and contained a lot of useful information. If taught slower the students will be able to grasp the concepts much better. 2- discussions should be based on students projects and how (if at all) the particular readings could be applied to the projects.
I appreciated when we started incorporating more of the student-generated questions into the class discussions.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: For MESc students, the course is instrumental for working through our summer research ideas and writing up a proposal that can later be used for grant applications

I am an MEM thinking of switching to an MESc so I took this course. I come from an anthropology background, so much of the course was review. The course helped me get a firmer grasp on the research I want to do next summer, and come up with a proposal for it.

The course is a good introduction to methods and analysis for social science research. However, it may be more beneficial for a similar course to be offered in the spring semester when student have a clearer idea of what they plan to do. I found it useful as a good motivation to get my summer analysis completed on time.
I will be doing research and hoped to learn new skills that can be applied to the research.
I had zero experience in this field so I wanted to round out my skills (coding surveys, etc.)
Required for MESc
For my MESc, this is the only required course. Seeing as I'd like to do research, but did very little formal research in my undergraduate degree, this course was key.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: My adviser suggested the course as I was interested in doing research this summer.
Planning to do research in social sciences.
Required course for MESc
Because I am an MEM thinking of switching to an MESc and I want to do research next summer.
Wanted to learn how to do research ad write a proposal.

I wanted to learn more about research methods and analysis since I had never taken a class on this topic before. I also needed some structure to get my thoughts organized and put together a coherent proposal for research.
To learn how to mix social and natural science research skills.

I'm planning on pursuing qualitative research this coming summer so I had to take this class. It was a good introduction but I'm planning on taking other methods class (ex. PoliSci dept) to really build my skill set.
Required for MESc

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: For the most part.
Yes, very helpful for research only.

Yes, although I don't feel as confident about the application of various methods as I probably could. Exercises explicitly practicing coding or writing ethnographic field notes and comparing them against our peers' or a model example could have been beneficial.
Yes!
Yes!
No they did not.

I was disappointed, I'll admit. It was a great introduction to a breadth of topics but I didn't at all feel like I could go out and conduct a research project this summer. I'm looking at other classes in other departments at Yale where I can get better experience. (see Q15)
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A

Depending on the groups and topics, some experiences were really good. At other times, people spent more time discussing how to go about doing a task than actually doing it which I felt was slightly counter productive. Perhaps having an idea about what to expect during group discussion for a particular day would save some time and allow students to prepare in advance.

Advantages: broadened parameters of thought. A diverse class brought a number of diverse views which was excellent. Disadvantages: If the group work was based on readings, sometimes no one in the group had a good answer for questions one person had and so in the end never received an answer for an important question/s.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Be sure you want to do research in the summer, otherwise the course is not ideal.
I would tell them that this is a good overview course, but don't expect to go in depth on the methods. It is a good way to think through your research for next summer.
Attend all the sessions and stick to the timelines.
Start working on your final paper from your first class. Ask questions to help you answer each of the headings required in the final paper.

While we covered a lot of methods this semester (and I appreciate this is probably the point), I don't really feel like I digested them. We only spent one week on interviews AND surveys which make up the bulk of many people's research this coming summer. Other schools similar to FES devote entire classes to this one topic. I felt like we did less practice and more reading/response questions/lecture. I would have really liked the class to be more hands on, especially outside the classroom. This is a great class to start you off but look for other methods classes at Yale to really build your skills before going out to the field!

When I took the course, we handed in our research proposals at the end of the semester. This didn't allow us to take advantage of the professors in polishing the proposals. I recommend you finish a solid draft much earlier and then work on improving it with the professors before the end of the semester.
